channel.title: Comments on: The future of scholarly publishing

item.title: By: Togel Online
item.dc:creator: Togel Online
item.description: I like to read your article because it really helps me. Thank you for sharing this post with us.
item.content:encoded: I like to read your article because it really helps me. Thank you for sharing this post with us.

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/the-future-of-scholarly-publishing/#comment-2706">@mrgunn</a>.
It's essentially cutting out the middle man. Funders could then use that to fund more sustainable ventures and additional research.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to @mrgunn.

It’s essentially cutting out the middle man. Funders could then use that to fund more sustainable ventures and additional research.

item.title: By: @mrgunn
item.dc:creator: @mrgunn
item.description: On the subject of the alleged billions of dollars that could be saved, where do they come from? Funders, right? How, then, can you claim publishers hold all the cards?
item.content:encoded: On the subject of the alleged billions of dollars that could be saved, where do they come from? Funders, right? How, then, can you claim publishers hold all the cards?

item.title: By: The future of scholarly publishing | Note...
item.dc:creator: The future of scholarly publishing  | Note...
item.description: […] we were to have to invent the scholarly publishing system again from scratch today, what would it look like? Our current system of publishing is basically identical to that of what it was in the 1990s, before the emergence of a vast array of internet-based technologies, loosely termed Web 2.0. A research paper is a 20th century format, published in a 17th century container – the journal. Ironically, this system still persists despite the blatant fact that anyone can publish anything they want at the touch of a button these days. Yet scholarly publishing still usually takes months, and some times takes even years, just to upload content to the Web.  […]
item.content:encoded: […] we were to have to invent the scholarly publishing system again from scratch today, what would it look like? Our current system of publishing is basically identical to that of what it was in the 1990s, before the emergence of a vast array of internet-based technologies, loosely termed Web 2.0. A research paper is a 20th century format, published in a 17th century container – the journal. Ironically, this system still persists despite the blatant fact that anyone can publish anything they want at the touch of a button these days. Yet scholarly publishing still usually takes months, and some times takes even years, just to upload content to the Web.  […]
